awd_titl_txt: LEAPS-MPS: Tunable Hybrid Materials for Studying Charge Transport
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

Non-Technical Summary 

Improvements in current solar energy conversion technologies are needed to meet the predicted 150% growth in global energy demand by 2050. With this LEAPS-MPS project, the PI is investigating the tunability of charge transport in thin films of hybrid metal-organic materials. Information obtained from this research will be useful in determining the structure-property relationships governing important charge transport-related processes and contribute to the rational design of materials for photovoltaic devices. Photovoltaics is considered one of the most promising technologies for meeting global energy demands. The research is conducted at a primarily undergraduate institution. It engages a diverse array of undergraduate students, including women, first generation college students (FGCS), and underrepresented minorities (URM) in high-impact research experiences both in teaching and research laboratories. To increase student participation in the STEM pipeline, the PI develops two remotely accessible laboratory activities for chemistry and biochemistry majors as part of this project. Additional activities include mentoring FGCS and URM students, and conducting online outreach workshops for local Girl Scouts (grades 4-8). To increase accessibility to thousands of people in the community, Prof. So disseminates teaching materials through conference presentations, workshops, online chemical education journals, and closed-captioned, free online videos. 


Technical Summary 

Improvements in solar energy conversion technologies require a better understanding of the structure-property relationships that govern charge transport. In this project, thin films of hybrid organic-inorganic materials, metal-organic framework (MOFs), of layered and pillared paddlewheel topologies are synthesized. The impact of the number of molecular linkers, pillars, and ionic components coordinated in MOF thin films on charge transport is quantified, and the relationship between guest molecules and charge transfer pathways in MOF films is probed using ab initio calculations and surface-sensitive spectroscopies. The obtained thermodynamic and spectroscopic datasets provide quantitative and qualitative structure-property relationships which relate MOF structure and composition to activation energy, band gap, and conductivity. Complementary education activities integrate remotely accessible laboratory activities into upper division chemistry laboratory courses and science outreach to increase technical skills and retain underrepresented minority, first generation students, and women in the STEM pipeline.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Current semiconductors used in solar panels are important for harnessing electricity for our daily use but have not reached maximum efficiency. This translates to solar panel customers needing to pay more per unit of electricity produced by the same amount of light. One way to increase solar energy conversion efficiency so that customers have lower solar panel expenses is to understand how charges generate electricity in semiconductive solids called metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). MOFs are modular platforms that help us model how different building blocks affect how charges move to maximize solar conversion efficiency.  

In this NSF funded research, a way to predict what building blocks are needed to create conductive MOFs more efficiently was developed. The intellectual merit of the project was to develop a computation-guided experimental approach to determine what building blocks are important to help charges move in MOFs. The computation was efficient at predicting what building blocks were needed to make MOF platforms that efficiently move charges. In experiments, the MOFs were built with selected building blocks to make charges move slower or faster. It was demonstrated that to fill in gaps within the MOF, bridges were needed to help charges move; otherwise, charges were stuck. It was also shown that push-pull building blocks within MOFs helped better facilitate charge motion. This work is fundamentally useful for chemists, materials researchers, and engineers in the semiconductor field.

The broader impacts of the research are important because efficient ways to predict what building blocks are needed to build conductive MOFs could help industry prepare semiconductors that convert solar energy more efficiently. Furthermore, five undergraduate researchers and one postdoctoral scholar were trained on how to conduct this materials chemistry research. One of the students is a first-generation college student, another is from an underrepresented subpopulation, and three are female. Two of the five are currently in PhD programs. All students use the skills they acquired while performing the NSF funded research. The postdoctoral scholar successfully transitioned to working at a primarily undergraduate institution. Additionally, an online workshop was developed as part of this project to train Girl Scouts to code and inspire them to pursue STEM. Also, two remotely accessible laboratory activities and dozens of closed-captioned free online videos were created to train up to 20 undergraduate students per academic year, many of whom are first-generation college students, from underrepresented subpopulations, or identify as women. Therefore, funding from this NSF project has helped recruit, retain, and diversify the materials chemistry pipeline.   


Last Modified: 12/19/2024
Modified by: Monica C So
